http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.value: This tag specifies that the associated annotation is a story

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: In the cable industry’s long history, there have been many interesting stories connecting past with present. These range from stories about cable companies’ conflicts with fishermen, which might educate users about the effects of local politics, to the impact of cable networks on the circulation of local information. Individual stories link between two and four individual sites in the network.

When building networks into remote environments, cable companies always have to negotiate with local ecologies. In California, negotiation turned to conflict in the late 1990s-early 2000s as environmental organizations such as the California Coastal Commission and the California State Lands Commission put up road blocks to technological development. Out on Midway Island, in the northern Pacific, cable companies actually created the environment: there was no vegetation prior to the cable station. In Cairns, Australia, builders had to find exits out through the Great Barrier Reef.
The environments that cables run through are not friction-free landscapes, but turbulent ecologies. Here, cable companies must grapple with the non-human world.

In the early 2000s, the cable market bust. So many cable systems were laid in the late 1990s that none of the cable companies got the high percentage of business that they had expected. The supply of cable capacity exceeded the demand. Many companies could not recoup the hundreds of millions of dollars expended to lay these networks. 360Networks, Global Crossing, Flag, Level 3, WorldCom, and Asia Global Crossing all went into bankruptcy between 2001 and 2002, some acquired for cents on the dollar. The Tyco Global Network transpacific network was acquired by Indian telecommunications giant Tata Communications. The companies then downsized drastically, often letting go of their most seasoned employees in order to save on salaries. But this savings also meant a loss – the workers' irreplaceable, embodied knowledge of the systems.

"It's either feast or famine," one cable station technician tells you. The history of the cable industry confirms this: it is littered with booms and busts. Cables are subject to risk and speculation. The most recent cable boom occurred in the late 1990s, alongside the dot com boom. Cable companies put massive amounts of fiber into the ocean. The privitization and deregulation of international telecommunications enabled new players to enter the network.

The final moment at which cables are joined is the splice. This can happen at cable landings or on boats in the middle of the ocean. Whether the cablemen are splicing together the copper core of a telephone cable or the strands of glass at the center of the fiber-optic cable, this is a moment that takes much skill. The cable station manager tells you that you are allowed to take pictures of everything except for the actual splice. This has to remain secret.

Many telegraph cable stations remain unexcavated, unknown, and insignificant to our historical landscape. The ruins at Guam are the only landing site even commemorated along the original Commericial Pacific Cable route and, as they are located on the military base, are not accessible to the public. The ruins at Midway Island cannot be accessed since there are no regular commercial flights to the atoll. Only military, research teams, and eco-expeditions that charter flights may visit.

Obsolete cables litter the seafloor. Old cable stations remain overgrown with weed. Some slip back into the jungle. Islands, once hubs of transnational communication, lie disconnected. Parts of our cable network are abandoned when the cost of upkeep is just too expensive.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/title.value: "Hopefully human ignorance will dissolve into silence"

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value:
The landing point of Honotua, Tahiti’s first fiber-optic cable, is marked by a stone monument. This is one of the only places in the world that memorializes an active cable. In Tahitian, English, and French, it reads:


In memory of the people of Papenoo and of Hawai‘i, who established ties in the past: Tapuhe‘euanu‘u from Tapahi, who, fishing from his canoe, caught Hawai‘i the Great, 
Te‘ura-vahine from Ha‘apaiano‘o, the goddess Pere, who sought refuge in the volcano of Hawai‘i the Great, 
Mo‘iteha, King of Hawai‘i, who came back to Tahiti to build his marae Ra‘iteha at Mou‘a‘uranuiatea, Ra‘amaitahiti, his son, King of Tapahi, who brought his drum to Kaua‘i, 
To revive these ancient connections, Honotua was made: The submarine cable that links Tahiti to Hawai‘i. 
After quietly undulating in the deep sea, it has landed here, at Mamu (silence). Hopefully human ignorance will dissolve into silence and only knowledge will be conveyed.

In some places, engineers report that fishermen deliberately fish around the cable in the hopes of being paid to stay away from it. Paying off the fishermen is one way to keeping them invested in the cable’s operation. A cable manager recounts that they initially had “fishermen problems” around SEA-WE-ME-3, but after buying a few licenses from them, the problem was solved: “So they got money, so we got rid of a point of aggravation. At the end of the day, we became sensitive to their concerns.”
Cable companies attempt to make the ocean stable place for internet development, but this clashes with fishermen’s need for mobility on the seas.

In the telegraph era, the cable man was the key gateway to the system. His smallest movements could have large-scale effects. One cableman recollects: “during our solitary watches of six hours, we were … the only links completing communication between Home and the Colonies ... Until relieved at the end of a duty, intercourse between Australia and the rest of the world depended entirely upon the man at the circuit.” Today, the work of cablemen is still important to the maintenance of the signal. They no longer have to perceive and retransmit a message, but they do have to regularly visit the cable station to check up on the equipment and ensure that everything is in order. Network engineers monitor traffic and repair broken lines. Without their work, our global communications networks would soon fail.
Even though we think of our information networks as less and less material, laying cable still depends on manual labor at a number of critical points.

Many in the telecommunications industry suggest that the advent of cloud  computing – which entails storing one’s data remotely, often outside of one’s  national boundaries – offers a cost-effective opportunity for developing  countries. Cloud computing would enable many islanders, even  those with low levels of domestic infrastructure, access to free internet-based applications  such as GoogleDocs and Skype. However, the Cloud would make  them remote communities even more dependent on external support to finance new infrastructure.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/title.value: Yap Federal States of Micronesia Telecommunications Corporation

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Most disruptions of cable networks are accidental, but cable engineers suspect that some are deliberate. One recalls a rumor that before their cables came into Morro Bay, there had been a nearby refinery with a pipeline extending out to sea. In order to keep the fishermen off the line, the refinery had compensated local  fishermen to stay away from the pipe. When the refinery closed, the engineer argued, the fishermen went “Ah! We need to find another source of income! Submarine cables!”

The movements of fishermen have brought about more significant and long-standing disruptions to cable systems than any design flaws, acts of nature, or unfriendly armies. After five years of work, the first undersea cable across the English Channel was completed – and then abruptly severed by a fisherman. A rumor circulated that the fisherman who raised it to the surface later exhibited it as a rare seaweed with a gold center. Over the years, cable companies have struggled with fishermen, and the governments that regulate them, to develop forms of protection: no-fishing zones, no anchorage zones, notices to mariners, penalties, and cable charts. The Atlantic Ocean has been the central battleground for this struggle.

Infrastructures are layered over infrastructures. Cables require an electrical grid. Stations have backup generators and battery plants inside to ensure that even if this grid fails, the station will never go offline. In many places, cable stations are located near large power plants. Along with electricity distributed through wires and circuits, some of these plants produce “dirty power” - a frequency that pollutes the airwaves and disrupts nearby radio signals. These fields make obvious the facile interception of wireless forms of communication.

Cables are resources and they depend on resources. Systems depend on electrical networks, transportation grids, and shipping lines. They’ve been used to transmit information about farming, mining, and global trade.

When tracking cables, look for bright colors, "Do Not Dig" signs, and other warnings for cable routes. These are almost always the remnants of local negotiations over cable routes. If you can read them correctly, you will find your way into the cable's history.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/title.value: San Luis Obispo Do Not Dig

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: With the collapse of the early 2000s, many companies scaled back. These companies lost a significant part of their labor force, and with it, the workers’ knowledge and experience. Years later, as the industry began to rebuild itself, much knowledge had been lost. Yet across history, cable stations have often lost their links, employees, and their status as part of the global network due to both market factors and natural disasters. In 1914, the station at La Perouse suffered a disastrous fire, and the cable was subsequently moved north to central Sydney.

The deep and dynamic ocean – with its currents, waves, gyres, and eddies – is generally considered the safest part of a cable route. Very few breaks occur in the deep ocean, where cables function for decades without interruption. Here they are safe from potential interference, from national interception to fishing traffic.

We often think about the internet as an urban matter, one that links large hubs around the world. And when we look at the ocean, we often see a natural and wild space. Most of our undersea cable network’s routes and pressure points, however, have been shaped by shifts in the aquatic environment.

Although wired and wireless technologies are often seen as competitors, in reality, cables and satellites have different geographies, markets, and technological strengths. Satellites, with their wide field of reception, have been more useful for rural areas, islands, and the transmission of television. Over the last twenty years, however, satellite capacity has filled up and traffic has shifted to cables. They are able to carry a greater amount of information at faster speeds and at lower cost. Many visible satellite dishes, mounted on rooftops and near telecom buildings, are relics of the past.

When we connect to the internet, we rarely do so by plugging in a wire. The internet is imagined as something that is located above us, bouncing through the air, in a “cloud.” Mobile phones, tablets, laptop computers, wireless routers, cell phone towers, and satellites direct our attention above rather than below.

The cable's beach landing, especially in the telegraph era, involved many men who helped to pull the cable ashore and an event watched by many local residents. In the later telephone and fiber-optic periods, it became less and less of an event, though images of cable landings are sometimes still posted on communications companies' websites.
Even though today's networks are often hidden from us, across history cable systems have been made visible to select publics.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/title.value: A station like a French chateau

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Some cable colonies were elaborately built complexes, intimidating in the surrounding area. The Bamfield cable station had multiple stories, sweeping hilltop views of the Barkley Sound, and was designed by a leading architect in Victoria, Francis Rattenbury. R. Bruce Scott, a cableman who worked there, compared it to a French chateau: it had close to fifty rooms, including telegraph offices, accommodations for servants and cablemen, a billiard room, a music room, and a library with books about the British Empire (jokingly referred to as the “All Red Room.”)

In some places, cable history is visibly infused into the sites it once connected. At Bamfield, commemorative Pacific Cable postage stamps are displayed in the marine sciences center lobby, a cable memorial stands on the center of the grounds, and signs around the site describe the function of the cable buildings.

Governments have historically valued fish over cables. In 1908, the British Parliament refused to limit fishing near cables, commenting that fishing “represents a capital of several millions, gives employment to a body of hardy and industrious men, and supplies a substantial part of the food of the people.” Cable companies were out of luck. After an Auckland-Suva cable was damaged in 1949, the New Zealand Marine Department suggested that the fault was in part the cable company's. They argued that if cables were just laid with enough slack they would fall “flat on the sea bed and so present little hazard to trawls.” Cable companies even tried to appeal to fishermen directly, meeting with fishing vessel owners’ associations and attending their exhibitions. Going to the fishing industry, they argued: “the world must have cables, for without cables you cannot sell your fish.”

Global Crossing’s abandoned cable station in Ma‘ili, several miles north of the Honotua cable landing, is marked with bullet holes. While cable stations were once central workplaces that enriched and enlivened communities, today they are more often inaccessible buildings whose benefit is often invisible to the surrounding residents. Here, residents didn’t embrace the system, but resisted it – the company encountered local dissent when they tried to lay cable beneath the town. In Hawai‘i, undersea cables are resisted by residents who see them in relation to the island’s colonial legacy.

Cable stations are buildings where undersea cables terminate after they come aground at a cable landing point. Here, transmitted signals, including dots and dashes, voices, and data are routed between systems. Stations are also social centers, places where cable men come together to maintain the network.

Many cable station buildings have been re-purposed for scientific uses. The station at Bamfield, Canada has since been transformed into a Marine Sciences Research Center. Scientists seeking new species near Wellington, New Zealand briefly utilized the cable house at Titahi Bay. Fanning Island, on the British line, used to be a destination on the Norwegian Cruise line until the company stopped needing an international location as part of its Hawaiian tours. For a period of time, the University of Honolulu Oceanographic Department leased the cable facility, and the cable stations were later turned into schoolhouses.

As they are laid and maintained, cables shape contours in the environment, leaving traces of their paths even after they are retrieved. These residual effects then make it more likely that new cables will be laid down existing paths, solidifying and sedimenting the network.

The expansion of cable systems depends on advances in marine science, from the mapping of the ocean's depths to the development of new subsea exploration technology. Cables themselves have also helped to generate new scientific knowledge.

Some cable stations in urban areas attempt to “blend in” with the cityscape in order to avoid interference. Instead of fences and cameras, they hide in plain view, looking like any other building in order to keep a low profile. While surveillance technologies focus on making the surrounding area visible to the station, this tactic focuses on making the station invisible to the public.
Submerged under miles of water for decades, cables are one of the least visible of all infrastructures. They are also deliberately hidden.

Colonial cable houses were massive and resilient structures that sheltered cablemen from the the threats of various frontiers. After the large telegraph crews were no longer needed, some of these structures were renovated for new purposes. The original cable station at Suva, Fiji now houses FINTEL, Fiji's international telecommunications carrier. In Darwin, Australia, after the cable station was bombed during World War II, the original cable manager's house was renovated and turned into a museum.
The creation of a cable network entails the production of a whole new set of architectures, including the built environment of the cable station.

Many early cable stations in the Pacific were located in remote sites. In some locations, like Broome this was out of geographical necessity, since it sat closer to Asia than other cities Australia. In other locations, stations were specifically placed to avoid urban hubs. Bamfield was chosen at a location in part because of its distance from a port. Today, many of these remote locations, disconnected from existing infrastructure, have been ceased to be cable centers.

Information about cables has often been withheld in a strategy of “security through obscurity.” The reasoning goes: if the public doesn’t know about the importance of undersea cables, they will not think to disrupt them. Many cable stations attempt to blend into the environment and deter attention from the building’s function. One cable builder says that they want to “make the building as non-descript as possible.”

Security has always been critical in cable network development. Companies plan and route systems so as to protect them from potential interference, from international censorship to the turbulence of the natural environment.

Look down, instead of to the sky, and you can see network infrastructure. If you follow the cable route toward the ocean, you might find a path carved out by foot traffic, establishing a connection between land and sea. This juncture of earth and water makes possible the landing of communications cables – infrastructures that accelerate the movement of information across the oceans.

Many operators feel that the greatest vulnerability of the current system is not mechanical nor electrical, but human. Some fear that there will be no one to take their place that knows the right way of doing things. Recruiting the next generation is difficult, since there is no direct educational path to the cable industry. It remains largely invisible to the public. “Nobody goes to school and says ‘I want to be in the undersea cable business,’” one cable CEO remarks.

In the April 1918 issue of The Zodiac: The Submarine Cable Service Paper, the editors write: “The Passing of a Cable Station should not go unrecorded and unsung, yet so we allowed La Perouse to vanish out of our official life.” Yet many cable stations have simply disappeared. At Ocean Beach in San Francisco, though numerous pictures were taken to document the cable landing, there are no indications of these infrastructures today or their historical role for global telecommunications.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/title.value: An earlier time in Fiji's history...

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: The satellite at the Vatuwaqa cable station in Fiji is a reminder of an earlier time in Fiji’s history, when the country had invested heavily in wireless communications. With the emergence of fiber-optic cables, Fiji found itself struggling to maintain a status as a hub for the South Pacific. In the late 1990s, Fiji decided to connect to the Southern Cross Cable Network, which involved generating an enormous amount of capital, $48.5 million, on its own. The debt acquired from the cable and the costs of maintenance led to a push in the early 2000s to develop media-heavy industries for new sources for signal flow.

Some early telegraph stations became tourist destinations open to the public. During summers, “droves of tourists” would arrive at the Bamfield cable station. A summer cruise to the Northland of New Zealand made the Doubtless Bay station a stop, and the superintendent greeted tourists on their trip. Given the repetitious nature of the job, station operators welcomed the visitors. Today, tours of stations are occasionally given to commemorate the opening of new systems.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/title.value: The social life of undersea cables

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: The link between two locations in a network is termed an “edge” in network theory. They are often drawn as a simple line between two nodes, a vector independent of time and place. We rarely see beyond its horizon, into the spaces where these connections are formed.

Nested in the wilderness, many cable stations became centers of social activity. In Fiji, tennis, rugby, and picnicking were popular pastimes, and several of the men owned boats, which they took out for weekend parties. Visiting other parts of the islands, they brought the chiefs the “customary bottle of whisky” in order to enjoy fishing in their lands.  On Fanning Island, the cablemen held canoe races and formed a Gun Club at which they shot clay pigeons. Bamfield had very little indoor entertainment until the cable station arrived, subsequent to which the following were established: a Saturday night movie open to the public, a dance hall with a five-piece cableman orchestra, and annual dances at the end of the summer and New Year’s (to which local residents would travel for hours to attend). “It was like living in a country club,” one cableman recounted.

Cables can be diverted, especially during wartime, from one landing point to another. The cable from Yap to Shanghai was diverted to Okinawa by the Japanese in 1916, and a second cable was diverted away from Yap to Palau during World War II. Other times natural causes, ranging from fires to typhoons, cause the relocation of cable hubs. The telegraph cable originally linking to La Perouse, Australia was diverted to Bondi Beach after a fire destroyed the station in 1914.

Being an undersea telegrapher was an exacting job. The global network spanned time zones and cablemen often had to work overnight to receive traffic during business hours in another part of the world. In the early days of telegraphy, operators sensed signals by watching a light move back and forth across a small strip, a practice that strained their eyes, and then retransmitted the signal on a connecting circuit, which strained their wrists. To make the signal visible, the men stayed in enclosed rooms where much of the light and air was blocked out.

Moving out into the Pacific from the coast, you hit the barrier reef. If cables are strung across them, they will chafe and soon break. To lay a system, one has to wind out through the reef's entrances, or in the case of the 1956 cable into Hanauma Bay, blast a hole in it. Today Hanauma Bay's reef entrance no longer services cables, but scuba divers, who move in and out of it to explore the bay's natural wonders.

Sandy beaches and a prime waterfront location once made these areas ideal for landing undersea cables, which require an easy transition between land and sea. Today these same features draw in tourists from around the region. The massive hotels, restaurants and bars, and even amusement parks ensure that the area will have reliable infrastructure, in turn supporting the operation of cable systems.

The invisibility of cables frustrates the cable industry's attempts to protect their infrastructure. One cable company's CEO says that her time is often spent answering the same question: “isn’t satellite bigger and faster and newer than cables?” When another cable industry leader, John Hibbard, met a local regulator at a cable meeting in Singapore, the man asked him: “Why am I here? Everything comes into the country via satellite.” This was stunning to Hibbard. “Singapore is about the most wired country in the world,” he says. “The only reason it doesn’t move is because it is tied down by all of these undersea cables.” If cables remain invisible to governments and policy makers, critical decisions about infrastructure funding – which could make networks more robust and accessible – will continue to be uninformed.

While in the coaxial era, stations were constructed like bunkers in order to protect against potential nuclear threats, today, security has to do with barriers and visibility in the station's perimeter. One cable station manager describes their facility as secure because it is located in a fairly isolated area, with high fences, barbed wire, and an automatic gate with video cameras operated by 24-7 staff who will only open it if they recognize the guest. There are about 60 actively monitored video cameras and the police regularly visit to make sure that there is nothing out of order. At night, barriers block off the roadway, giving them “multiple layers of protection.”
Cables don't always extend smoothly through the world, but come up against conflicts - from both people and nature.

At some landing points, monuments commemorate cable history. At Southport’s "cable park," a monument commemorates the Pacific Cable Board telegraph system. A large map, engraved in metal, shows the colonial routes across the Pacific. A quote from Shakespeare, “I’ll put a girdle round about the earth in forty minutes,” anchors the system in British history. In Northland, New Zealand and Darwin, Australia stones mark the spot of the original cable landing. Few of these monuments are located near existing cable landing points.

Many cables were linked to Chinese treaty ports in the 1800s and early 1900s. These were intended to help "open up" the Chinese economy to trade with Western nations. Even today, cables are positioned as a technology that will help integrate developing economies with the global economy.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/title.value: Great Northern Telegraph Company station at Shanghai

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Even as far back as the nineteenth century, cables have been used as ways to open up developing areas by linking them into modern communications systems.

Cable stations and networks have been critical sites during wartime. The same sandy beaches that make locations appropriate for cables to come ashore have also made them desirable landing points for marine forces. At Anson Bay, Australia and Tumon Bay, Guam guns were mounted on the beach during World War II. Today, tourists headed to the installations on Guam’s Gun Beach have little knowledge of the cable conduits they must step over.

While American stations often blend into their environment, in other sites stations are surrounded by twelve foot walls. Cable stations are not all the same, and the strategies for insulating cable traffic reflect the threats of each particular environment. In the Philippines, walls keep locals on the ground out of the station. Approaching it, you can't even see inside from the street.

Cables have long been seen as ways to facilitate economic development. An 1894 article about the cable to Labuan island notes that the cable will materially assist in the development of the British Mines there, then being worked by the New Central Borneo Company, Ltd.. A railway was to be connected between the mines and the shipping port, and in turn to the cable landing. The author writes, "Doubtless one effect of the cable will be to stimulate every branch of industry, and to beneficially affect both the export and import trade, not only in that Colony, but in the adjourning territories.”

While in the colonial era, the cable station's walls were porous, in the Cold War era, people who were not “part” of the network were rarely allowed inside. Concerns about regulating access and protecting circuits permeated discussions of the period. Visitors were typically permitted entrance only when accompanied by officers who had been cleared. Cablemen were regularly reminded that the work done within the station was not to be shared with others who could not enter. One author remarks, “Growing up in Heart’s Content in the 1950s, unless your father worked at the cable station you probably never got to see inside the door” – a significant change from the telegraph stations, which accommodated tourists and encouraged public participation in station events.

Political ties can facilitate the development of international communication. Cable companies have to get permission from nations to land on their soil. New political arrangements can then result from these connections. Recent projects that link un-cabled locations, such as the Interchange cable to Tonga and the Honotua cable to Tahiti, build on long-standing territorial alliances.

Many cable stations had to confront extraordinary storms, which would at times disrupt the cablemen's lives, or even the cable station itself. In Rio de Janeiro, one letter from the Superintendent from the station reports: “the terrible storm on the night of the 19th inst. has rendered the building in most parts dangerous and uninhabitable… There were only three bedrooms dry, all the others were inundated; beds and personal effects were all drenched.” Given the station’s limited budget, they had barely enough money for silverware. Where it lacked adequate insulation, the station’s operations were jeopardized, not only through structural damage, but also though the operators’ morale since poor living conditions could affect their accuracy.

The narrow points where cables run together are pressure points, sites where currents can be diverted or re-routed using minimal force. Here, local actors often have a disproportionate amount of power.

The training of cable operators conditions both the body and the mind. The first telegraph signals on undersea cables had to be written out in full and retransmitted, and early operators had to cultivate both the correct wrist action and a steady focus to endure long hours of writing. Then, as is still true today, much of the knowledge of cable operation is passed down informally from generation to generation via on-the-job training.

Remote station employees were subject to natural phenomena that could disrupt their work - hurricanes, snowstorms, heat waves. In its early days, Guam’s cablemen faced difficulties in obtaining water (it had to be carted in from another town), problems with tropical insects, and were not allowed to purchase fresh meat or ice from government stores.  Many station employees fell ill. Cablemen in Newfoundland had to cope with below freezing weather. In Darwin, white ants consumed the insides of walls.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/bibliographicCi.value: Letter from Percy Geo, Padbury Superintendent; in Barty-King, Girdle Round the Earth, 118.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Arriving here, you find the cable marked on a nautical chart. These squiggly route lines have long been drawn as an attempt to keep fishermen and other boaters off the cable route. If fishermen don't know where the cable lies, they might accidentally drop an anchor on it, severing the connection.

The ocean itself serves a medium for signal traffic. For current to move through any electrical system, the circuit needs to be “grounded,” that is, wired to a point with lower electrical energy. In the case of undersea cables, a signal moves through the cable across the ocean, and then the circuit completes via an “ocean ground bed,” a technology that redirects electrical current back through the ocean itself. As one cable report observes, powering a system “is achieved by actually using the environment – the seawater – as a conductor to complete the circuit.” In contrast to our view of the ocean as stormy, unwieldy, noisy, and unstable, cable infrastructure harnesses the watery environment to transmit signals.

The friction-free operation of the cable station directly depends on its interconnection with other friction-free local infrastructures, especially the road. When roads are blocked, maintenance can be delayed and networks made inaccessible.
Here, cables land on or near sacred grounds, places of worship, forbidden sites. They intersect a rich and deep spiritual history.

Colonial cable stations, referred to as "cable colonies" or "frontier stations," often were large buildings and centers of community in remote areas. These stations were self-sufficient and insular spaces where cable companies reproduced a microcosm of empire.

Colonization helped to set the stage for cable networks. The British All-Red Line extended around the world, stopping only on British colonies and helping to protect the empire. The American Commercial Pacific Cable was laid in part to help solidify the United States' Pacific Empire.

Where transoceanic cable networks once extended, there are now large seafloor observatories, undersea cable networks that connect scientific instruments on the bottom of the ocean. In the Pacific Northwest, the NEPTUNE network and the Regional Scale Nodes project enable scientists to communicate with the ocean itself, tracking seafloor processes as they occur in real time. These built on investments in earlier systems. NEPTUNE's researchers conduct maintenance from the Bamfield Marine Sciences Centre; and up the inlet at Port Alberni, it terminates in a cable station built for a 1960s coaxial system. The Regional Scale Nodes project links up an old cable station built for a fiber-optic transpacific link.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/title.value: "we have the best Cable Colony in the world"

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Guam’s cable station had its own sailing crew, automobiling parties, billiards tournaments, and even attempted a swimming pool installation. In 1917, the Guam News Letter reports: “Guam was taken by storm, notwithstanding a rising barometer, when the Cable Station Dance Club broke loose in Sumay on August 18th, and all hands hope for repetitions. We are convinced that we have the best Cable Colony in the world here in Guam and we voluntarily undertake to defend that title. ... The floor was all to the good par exellence, the music inspiring, the weather made to order, the grounds were transformed into a Garden of Eden, and the automobiles were so numerous as to necessitate parking the surplus in the vegetable gardens.”

Cable stations were the vibrant and visible nodes of early telegraph networks. Far from the secrecy that surrounds the station today, cable stations and landing sites were drawn on commemorative cable envelopes, postcards, and postage stamps, and at times their addresses were even indicated on the delivered cablegram.

On February 19, 1942, Japanese aircraft bombed Darwin, damaging the British Australian Telegraph Company building and the first Darwin Post Office. Nine officers lost their lives on duty. Today, the Northern Territory Parliament House, rebuilt on the site, contains the offices for the government and legislative council. One wall of the original communications building remains embedded in the reconstruction, described on an accompanying plaque as "an enduring memorial of past devotion."

Like seaports and airports, cable stations are gateways, places that function as a region’s entry or exit point. Here, different forms of traffic are interconnected: transportation routes are leveraged to support labor, biopower is channeled to transfer information, and electrical grids are harnessed to transmit signals under the ocean. Gateways are strategic locations, centers of power where messages can be delayed, censored, or intercepted.

Laying reliable cables requires immense knowledge about the ocean’s depth and composition. If cables are draped across valleys, they risk being caught in currents. If they are routed diagonally down steep slopes, they might be broken by landslides. If laid across sunken ships or coral reefs, they could become twisted and tangled.

After World War II, simply placing a cable station on one's territory could not secure it from nuclear bombs. Many stations were located underground in fallout shelters. Installations on U.S. territory, including those at Guam and Hawai'i, had to be built according to military specifications with walls between 18 and 24 inches thick. There were showers where employees could wash off radioactive material and kitchens stocked with food in the case of an attack. These forms of protection were termed “hardening.”

AT&T has been integral to the laying of submarine cables since the 1950s. During the Cold War period, cable laying was "club" affair - only nationally-affiliated telecommunications companies could participate. AT&T facilitated all of the United States' transoceanic projects during this time, and built an number of cable stations on US shores.

The culture of the Cold War affected cable companies’ decisions about the expansion of coaxial systems in the 1950s. Undersea cables gave stability and secrecy to international calls, which might have otherwise been intercepted over the airwaves. Cable stations were fortified. The network began to resemble what Paul Edwards called “The Closed World.”

Here, communities harness the flow of cable company money across their environment. Locals have been empowered by state laws to make demands of the cable companies. In 1990, when installing a cable in Central California, AT&T constructed a beach manhole and a parking lot that improved visitors’ access to the state park. Today, the lot enables cable companies access to their network as well as surfers' access to the waves. Even though cable companies helped to expand access, when they land cables there today, they also inhibit it, blocking off the areas to route their cable underground. At times they are asked to contribute a "Mitigation Fee" (at one point $55,000) to compensate the park. This money, too, would be used to expand park access.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/bibliographicCi.value: AT&T Asia America Gateway Fiber Optic Cable Project Draft Environmental Impact Report, prepared for California State Lands Commission (December, 2008) online at: http://www.slc.ca.gov/division_pages/depm/depm_programs_and_reports/att/att.html.

E-08-021, CC-005-09 (AT&T Corporation), ADDENDUM TO COMMISSION PACKET FOR ENERGY, OCEAN RESOURCES, and FEDERAL CONSISTENCY For Friday, March 13, 2009; Submitted to the California Coastal Commission. Online at: documents.coastal.ca.gov/reports/2009/3/F5a-3-2009.pdf.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Political dissidents and criminals were once housed on these islands, where remoteness severed them from society. The climate was harsh and labor conditions brutal. Only signals escaped via undersea telegraph cables, helping those in power keep tabs on the situation abroad.

Stamps and souvenir sheets were also released to commemorate the establishment of undersea cables - they showed images of cable landing stations, maps of the cable route, and images of the countries that were connected.

Moving out from the cable station, where signals are monitored, powered, and processed, towards the deep sea, undersea cables must first traverse roads, beaches, and coastal waters inhabited by aquatic creatures and terrestrial publics. This zone is the cable landing point, described in the industry as a “transition environment.” While the cable station has been conceptualized as a potential target throughout its history, the cable landing point has rarely been seen as an area needing protection.

Cable routes, especially in tropical locations, have to consistently cleared, mowed, and patrolled. Sometimes they have to be dug up to make way for new lines. Maintenance is a resource intensive process that consumes a regular part of the stations operating budget. Without it, our networks would soon be overgrown.
Standing at the individual nodes of our networks, you can see the conflicts, contestations, and negotiations that shape cable systems under water.

Telegraph companies relied on local laborers for all sorts of tasks, from cooking to gardening. Indigenous people helped to drag cables ashore and dig trenches for terrestrial links. At times, local labor was considered “unsuitable,” and servants would be sought from China and India. In their review of Rodriguez Island, the Eastern Extension company reports: “It is advisable to obtain Cooks and Butlers from Mauritius as local material unsuited to these positions... Other servants obtained locally.”

Before the telegraph, trains were an important mode of long distance communication. Like many other new media forms, telegraphs both layered onto and extended existing networks. They were used to enhance the reliability of trains and were often centered in hubs of railway transit.
Manholes are some of the only places where cable systems appear in public space. Here, workers descend underground to access their systems.

In the 1940s and 1950s, oceanic space was surveilled and militarized. The United States military developed a secret network of undersea cables that served as listening posts for Soviet submarines. Their Sound Surveillance System, developed by AT&T, used hydrophones to monitor subsea space for national enemies.

Network repair can be difficult, only in part due to the hassle of retrieving cables from miles below the ocean. In some places, including China, Italy, and Indonesia, companies have had to wait to receive permits before they can fix their systems. Cable repair is also dependent on a limited number of specialized cable ships.

Many early island hubs have been skipped over as future telegraph, telephone, and Internet cables extended across the Pacific. Without continuing to host these circulations, the communications systems often lagged behind. Without political interest or philanthropic good will, cable companies rarely stop at islands on their way across the Pacific – they need to find quicker and “safer” routes to be competitive.

At the turn of the twentieth century, Orientalism was alive and well in San Francisco, among many other parts of Europe and America. Chinese goods were in demand and the new telegraph cable was seen as a connection that could spark further trade between East and West. The Pacific Telephone and Telegraph Company's San Francisco building even had a China office, decorated with intricate Asian design and staffed by young Asian women. A description of the architecture reads: "The ceiling itself is frankly and splendily Chinese, with grotesque parades of heraldic monsters incised in a field of faded coral and burnished in pale bronze... The effect is at once strange, restful, gorgeous and yet severe. It typifies the rich redundant Orient disciplines to Occidental purposes".

http://purl.org/dc/terms/bibliographicCi.value: Buildings. Engineering and Contracting Publishing Company, Chicago, January, 27 1926, p. 12.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/title.value: Pacific Telegraph and Telephone Company building

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Every once in a while, in the midst of stormy seas, heavy tides, and eroding sand, an old telegraph or telephone cable surfaces on the beach. Such surfacings are at times reported in local news, but stories rarely extend beyond an initial “Aha!” moment. Like the cable, they appear out of nowhere and soon slip into the background.

The direct environmental impacts of an undersea cable, even plowing it into the seabed, are small. Once they are buried, they might remain in place for 25 years or more, becoming a home to undersea creatures. The more extensive environmental impact comes from the power needed to keep data centers operating and the reorganization of the material world to be able to support internet infrastructure.

The jungle in Guam grows quick and dense. If it is not cleared regularly, it will obscure the sight-lines between cable station and ocean, overshadow the markers indicating the cable route, and make access to infrastructures difficult.

Most of the undersea cable network’s routes and pressure points are nestled among “natural” environments, and the system has been profoundly shaped by the politics of rural and island locations. As a result, much of Australia and New Zealand’s cable infrastructure is shaped by the histories of Hawai‘i and Fiji. On California’s west coast, traffic often exits the country via remotely located hubs in San Luis Obispo and Manchester rather than Los Angeles or San Francisco.

Before cables crossed the seas, ships were bearers of transoceanic messages and goods. Rivers and channels were the circuits for communication. Cables are often laid along such waterways, linking cities into networks of exchange.

Cables are important, and some say even essential, to islands with developing economies: they can increase reliability for weather reporting, including tsunami warning systems, and support higher bandwidth applications for less money, assisting in development. Reflecting on the recent installation of the HANTRU-1 cable, the President of the Marshall Islands Telecommunications Authority claimed: “Connecting to the global fiber optic network promises to be nothing short of transformational for an isolated country such as the Marshall Islands.”

Disconnected from the global undersea network, these locations remain without cables. In some places, systems were left on the bottom of the seafloor after they broke, their inscriptions often removed from cable maps and nautical charts. In others, cables were retrieved, used as links for less populous locations or at times, turned into artificial reefs. Still others await even their first cable connection.

Images and narratives of a cable’s connection are the most widely circulated forms of cable discourse. These synchronize well with both publicity and security: they first cultivate support for networks and, since they end at the moment of connection, help us to forget that those networks continue to operate.

Wireless telegraphy needed much less investment than setting up expensive, labor-intensive undersea systems. These new technologies made it possible for many small islands and remote locations to become nodes in transoceanic signal networks.

Offshore development has been a market for undersea cables since the coaxial era, but as platforms are extended further and further out to the sea, they became more dependent on effective communications, especially the secure lines of cable systems, to manage their activities. Cables have been deployed to platforms around the world, from Brazil, to Azerbaijan, to Australia. Cables not only link installations to land, but to instruments on the bottom of the seafloor.

As they emerged during the 1990s, private cable networks competed with the older, consortium-run systems which had long run the undersea network. While consortium systems often had upfront financing, private networks had to convince banks to lend them hundreds of millions of dollars. The first fiber-optic private cable system in the Pacific was North Pacific Cable, linking Miura, Japan, with Oregon and Alaska in the United States.

Fiber optic systems, which encode signals in light and send them down a thread of glass, have been in development since the early 1980s. Given the conservatism of the industry, the first international system was not put in place until 1986. The immense capacity of these systems have made possible the internet as we know it today.

In the fiber-optic era, the undersea network was “opened up.” In 1984, AT&T, the world’s largest telecommunications provider, was broken up. The Japanese began to deregulate the monopoly of NTT in 1985. British Telecom and France Telecom were sold to private investors. This created opportunities for smaller carriers and enabled larger companies to operate cables in places previously protected by consortium interests. Many cable projects became speculative money making ventures that involved calculating market risk, rather than “supporters of national industry and public service.”

Following deregulation, private cables developed a new geography of landing points, since existing companies often blocked the new networks from terminating at their stations. While many historical monopolies resisted the change, in the end, the new nodes were interconnected with the old ones, and the boom helped to create duplicate routes across the oceans and ultimately, a more secure network.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/title.value: Harbour Pointe Pacific Crossing cable station doors

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Technical interconnection is important in cable management. The network is stronger when companies build bridges to each other to transfer signals across their systems. Networks are also strengthened when interconnections are established with to surrounding populations and locals benefit from the systems.

Cables not only transmit information across the oceans, but can register processes in the ocean around them. Early telegraphs could record signals generated by the earth’s magnetic currents. During and after World War II, the U.S., British, and Soviet navies installed cable arrays to detect enemy presence. The U.S. system, SOSUS, scanned both the Atlantic and the Pacific for decades. Today, cables are used by marine scientists to detect underwater phenomena such as tsunamis and study marine life.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/title.value: Deploying a hydroacoustic array at Wake Island

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: These locations are critical nodes, where power is embedded in more than just cable routes. These are sites where companies can draw from layered support infrastructures, blocked outward transmissions can be re-routed (inward traffic is less easily diverted); and economic surpluses are more easily generated.

Cables increase the susceptibility of media to surveillance and censorship. British control of telegraph networks in the 1900s gave the country the ability to intercept and censor messages, especially during wartime. The U.S. control over telegraph networks in the Philippines helped the United States to develop as a surveillance state. Cable surveillance capacities are still being leveraged today. The British Government Communications Headquarters and the National Security Agency are both known to collect information as it passes through fiber-optic links.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/title.value: Receipt between Hong Kong and Manila

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Surfers hover over cable landing points, waiting to catch the right wave to shore. The turbulent waters of the surf zone, which appeal to surfers, make it the most difficult part of the cable landing. If lines were not encased in metal ducts, the waves here might push them across the seafloor, chafing and severing the connection.
Cable stations today are often landed in areas where property values are low. It's not surprising to find discarded objects, trash, and litter near the landing point.

In the telegraph era, cables were sometimes draped between undersea hills, and whales became entangled in them. The only conflict between fiber-optic cables and large marine animals dates back to the mid-1980s, when cable laid off the African coast was severed by shark bites. The industry quickly adapted after this disruption by adding an extra insulating layer that blocked the shark-attracting frequency. Today, cables rarely interfere with the movements of aquatic creatures.

The undersea network will never connect all of the world’s remote islands. There will always be populations that are too expensive and not profitable enough to reach. Despite the expanses of the global cable system, there remains a multi-tiered communication system and a digital divide.

We often come to know about cable systems only at the moment of their disconnection or failure. The severing of undersea cables by the 2006 earthquake off the coast of Taiwan alerted many people, for the first time, that their internet came from beneath the sea.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/title.value: Trying to get a line on a historic cable

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: In 1990, a resident at Mon Repos Beach found an old cable while swimming and, thinking it might be dangerous, tied a tree trunk to it. Reporting on the incident, the local newspaper staged a playful photo in which a young girl kneeling in the tides, holding a phone to her ear, and trying her luck to get a line on the historic telegraph cable.

The epicenter of the 2006 Hengchun earthquake was located off Taiwan's southern coast, and right over the route lines of several major Pacific cables. Undersea, sediment shifted, causing a sub-sea landslide that snapped nine cable links, affecting service as far away as India. Immediately following the aftershock, over 10% of Indian-originated networks were severed from the rest of the Internet. Following these breaks, cable companies pioneered a new set of routes, including landings in sites such as Ballesteros, in the Philippines.

When radio communication was developed, it did not replace undersea cables. As one reporter observed in the 1920s: “The truth of the matter is that wireless and cable communications supplement one another." He adds, "but the use of the cable... has one outstanding advantage over wireless – secrecy.”

Cables are subject to the winds of typhoons, the rising waters of a turbulent ocean, and sudden movements of the earth’s tectonic plates. Landslides and fires threaten to take out cable stations from nearby hills. These are places where natural disasters endanger global communications.

The most spectacular and extensive cable disruptions have been from earthquakes. Yet the earthquake itself is rarely the source of the cable break. Rather, these geological shifts often cause undersea landslides and turbulence on the sea floor, which in turn sever the network.

Ports are both a benefit and threat to cables. While many early links overlaid shipping lines, strung between ports across the Pacific, cable layers soon came to find that ships’ anchors were their most frequent disruption. Care was taken to dislocate many cables from ports, despite the exchange of traffic between the two.

To “sell” the COMPAC cable to users who might be skeptical of long-distance calls, the cable’s management committee cultivated news coverage about the cable in print, radio, and television, contacted journalists and camera crews to document the landings, arranged speeches about the system, and encouraged schools to “adopt” and follow Cable and Wireless cableships. They launched their own multi-media blitz, publishing photos of the cable buildings, distributing booklets with material on the cable’s design and installation, tracking the cable ships, and issuing special stamps to commemorate the cable. To culminate the laying, they staged elaborate opening ceremonies with souvenir programs. Some were even covered by live television.

Since the beginning of cable work, cablemen have mediated station happenings in telegraph journals and magazines. The Eastern Telegraph Company’s monthly “family magazine,” The Zodiac, was widely circulated around the globe. These were arenas where cablemen, separated by oceans, shared their experiences in remote locations.

In the telegraph era, cable companies maintained a distinct social composition, tightly controlling the national affiliation of the cablemen. Stations operated by British companies were initially staffed only with British workers. Local men were not often trained as operators, despite the fact that the men from abroad were not necessarily more qualified. On site accommodation also kept cablemen from finding homes in nearby towns. These policies made sure that workers would maintain their connections to a distant homeland and prevented information, expertise, and resources from diffusing to those outside of the cable colony.

While support has been channeled in for many new cables, the remnants of infrastructure failure remain. Destroyed cable stations are yet unexcavated, wireless towers remain standing, and detritus of former networks is scattered across the Pacific.

The typical cable map portrays the cable as a simple line of connection between major cities, or even just countries. The environments cables are laid through – the oceans, coastal landing points, and terrestrial routes – are friction-free geographies leveled by telecommunications. These maps make it difficult to actually find undersea cables.

In Hawai‘i, the politics of one road have made it difficult to land international systems. Farrington Highway is a central route for those on the island’s west shore: for the military, for industries, and for local communities. In 1999, when AT&T dug up the road to reconnect its stations, the disruption in the daily lives of local communities caused an outcry and the cable station manager tells me that some of the residents came to think of AT&T as the “enemy.” He tells me that he spends much of his time addressing the claims of residents in the towns along Farrington Highway, a site that he describes as “one way in and one way out.”

To triangulate one's networks involves positioning them as a mediating point for existing flows, an in-between for global circulations. Yap was once an important network node, but its connectivity now depends its ability to triangulate flows between Guam and Palau.

Cable landings are sites of attraction, places where the cables surface in public discussion. At the moment they are first established, cables are a cause for celebration. Often, large public ceremonies are held. Notable figures speak over the wire. In these moments, it is not only the technology that is being celebrated, but the colonial empire or the nation.

In the cable industry there has long been a shared culture. The Chairman of Cable & Wireless once wrote: “The company is, in fact, a huge continuing international family.”  Another cableman reflected that the cable system “was like an extended family. Wherever you went in the world, if you visited a cable station, you were bound to meet someone you knew or had heard about.”  The technicians, operators, engineers, and managers respect each other’s work and see the construction and operation of global cable networks on the whole as a collaborative activity, work that they take pride in.

Islands are critical to Internet communication even though cables can span the Pacific in a single hop. More than half of the nodes in our undersea cable network are still located on islands. These “networked islands” are places where one can tap into and re-route flows as they pass by.

In the Cold War era, people who were not part of the network were rarely allowed inside the station. Cable station tours were few and far between. Yet on one rare occasion, to commemorate the Canadian Overseas Telecommunications Corporation’s “birthday” in 1975, local residents were given tours of the cable station building. They were shown the equipment room, power room, and storage depot, as well as a number of exhibits that demonstrated the company’s abilities in cable operation and repair.

Cables are sometimes laid even when a location already has enough capacity. This is in order to generate diversity – multiple, disparate pathways to a node – which makes traffic overall more reliable. Australia used to be one of the most diversely connected countries, with at least six zones where telegraphs landed. Over the years this decreased: much traffic has run through Sydney. Recent proponents for landing a cable in Perth have argued that the country needs to diversify its routes again.

At the opposite end of the spectrum from the fiber-optic super-station is a modern version of the “cable hut,” smaller in scale and built just big enough for the capacity running through it. One engineer describes these to me as “functional equipment buildings,” and from the outside they often look like windowless office buildings, blending into an industrial landscape.

The geography of signal distribution remains centralized in key locations. Only forty-five undersea cables extend outward from the continental United States, supporting almost all international data traffic. This number is high if one looks across the globe. Many countries’ external links number under five. These stations are central hubs for network traffic.

Urban hubs have been variously seen as a source of danger, since they bring potential disruptions, and as a source of protection. In the post World War I period, some cable stations were relocated to be closer to major cities, which would offer protection. Following World War II, many systems were removed from urban centers to keep them from threatening populations and nuclear bombs.

During the cable boom, a series of fiber-optic “super-stations” were built. These are often meticulously designed, completely redundant, enormous station constructed in anticipation of future cable growth. They often have extra room to offer to other cable systems or to rent as “colocation” space, which other companies can use for data centers, call centers, or services for content generation.

The cable's installation has all but disappeared from sight. While early systems required teams of men to dig long trenches, today the technique of horizontal drilling uses machines to extend the conduit beneath land and sea.
In the telegraph era, cabled islands were key sites of political and military power. They constituted a “cable threat” to any country that sought to control the land and seas of the Pacific.

In some places, obsolete cables are drawn up from the seafloor and re-laid to connect un-cabled islands. The PacRim West cable, a transpacific link, was retrieved from the ocean and used to construct a new connection to Port Moresby, Papua New Guinea: APNG-2.

Early cable stations were often self-sufficient and insular spaces. Guam’s cable station, like many of that time, was “self-contained”: it was intended to be fire, earthquake, and typhoon proof, with its own water supply, sewage and refrigeration system (including an ice plant), and it was lit using acetylene gas manufactured on site.

In the 1920s, a regenerator system was deployed across the undersea network. This re-boosted the telegraph signal at cable station, effectively replacing human operators with automatic relay systems. While in the early days, a message from England to New Zealand and back might be handled thirty-eight times at nineteen stations along the way, by 1940, a message could be sent direct with no human contact.
When there is a telecommunications monopoly or duopoly, one or two companies carry all traffic in and out of a country. They can keep prices of capacity high and limits its citizens’ access.
These are hubs of commercial activity, where cables speed up both communications and economic exchange.

Despite the automation of many tasks, human labor remained important to the operations of the undersea telephone network. A significant staff of technicians performed routine maintenance on the systems, including testing circuits, coordinating network traffic, and monitoring the extensive terminal equipment – the stations were often manned twenty four hours a day and seven days a week.

To track cable systems, you must follow their markings: spray painted lines on the concrete, faded orange “Buried Fiber Optic Cable” posts planted alongside the road, and warning signs mounted on cable stations.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/title.value: San Luis Obispo cable route sign

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Wake Island has long been a temporary landing ground, a launching point, a space of transition. In the 1930s, Pan Am flights stopped at Wake on their way across the Pacific, and this hotel was built to house them. Today, contractors and military men come and go, importing food, filtering seawater, conducting research, and scanning the Pacific. Like the signals and planes that once passed through it, few stay here for long.

Undersea cables are a specialized product. Only a few companies manage their design and construction. They are assembled around the world, in places from New Hampshire, in the United States, to Kitakyushu, Japan, to Singapore.

Instead of defending from attack from above, today’s cable stations protect communication from potential terrorist attacks on or close to the ground. This entails creating a “buffer zone” around the station in order to make it difficult to see, and access, from the outside. Immediately after 9-11, the military surrounded several cable stations on United States soil because they were considered possible targets. The number of cameras monitoring the stations increased. In some places, trees around the station have been cleared out and proximate infrastructures relocated. Cable stations want to see all but be seen by none.

The invisibility of undersea cables enabled the extension of these networks to places where they might have otherwise been opposed. When there was resistance to the installation of the telegraph in China because it conflicted with customary beliefs (the Chinese government rejected plans to link land telegraph lines to treaty ports), undersea cables were secretly brought ashore in the middle of the night.

The basic expense of running networks on tropical islands is much higher than they would be in urbanized or highly developed locations. Communications companies face maintenance challenges, including managing temperature, moisture, and the level of salt in the environment. They have to invest in extensive power-intensive air-conditioning. Infrastructural limitations cascade for those on the outer edges of the network.

The relative centralization of cable systems and their embeddedness in existing territories make our networks far less resilient than we imagine. In 2006 an earthquake near Taiwan set off an undersea landslide and snapped several cables. Another significant outage happened in Vietnam in 2007 when cable thieves pulled up several of the country’s working lines. Since then, there have been a number of network breaks that shut off the country’s internet connection. While network carriers are often able to re-route traffic, in many cases, breaks have cause decreased Internet connectivity.

Cable stations rely on a number of sources to power the movement of data alongside the systems that support the building’s functioning: battery plants, local electrical grids, and backup power generators. The power bill for a single station can be tens of thousands of US dollars a month.

In Rudyard Kipling’s poem, “The Deep-Sea Cables,” he describes the telegraph cables’ seafloor environment: “The wrecks dissolve above us; their dust drops down from afar; Down to the dark, to the utter dark, where the blind white sea-snakes are; There is no sound, no echo of sound, in the deserts of the deep; Or the great gray level plains of ooze where the shell-burred cables creep.” Here, the earth and the depths of the ocean seem far apart, even though human communication depended on movement through the deep sea.

Following transmissions and tracking movement between nodes, you start to see the network differently. It is not something out in the atmosphere, seemingly nonmaterial. It is a set of buildings and people, technologies and raw materials, economic circulations and cultural practices.

To lay a cable properly, one must adeptly navigate the seas. In the telegraph era, with astronomical navigation alone, ships could not discern their exact location, especially out of view of land. Even through the 1960s, navigational issues made the accurate laying of cables difficult. With the use of satellite technologies and GPS navigation today, cable ships can precisely locate the cable on the seabed.
From the early telegraph through the coaxial era, undersea cables had a conductive copper core.

In the 19th century, the first undersea network extended around the globe. The British pioneered this effort, drawing upon their technical expertise and naval resources. Many of these early systems followed colonial transportation and trade routes.

Underlying the technical infrastructure of undersea networks is a tight-knit cable community. Many have been in the industry for decades, and almost everyone knows everyone. These men and women often have a shared sense of purpose in creating and upholding the communications system and linking their nations to the world.

The seafloor survey is a critical part of cable laying. Engineers believe that the better the map, the more durable their system will be. While early telegraph surveys were conducted by throwing a weighted line overboard, today’s cable surveyors have computers that can continually index the ocean beneath them. This information is valuable and isn’t typically shared with others. As one engineer reports, making it publically available “would be giving competitive advantage to other people.”

The shortest cable route, the one with the least "latency," has gained a new premium with the development of the Internet. Microseconds make a difference to high frequency traders who use computational algorithms to take advantage of slight changes in price in different locations. Companies who have a more direct connection can exploit this for profit. It has been estimated that merely a few milliseconds can result in a $20 million dollar difference in the span of a month.
Like these bridges span waters, cables bridge continents, bringing together diverse cultures, practices, and forms of communication.
Terrestrial wires can remain without an insulating layer because air keeps signals from diffusing. Without insulation, signals on undersea cable traffic would dissipate into a conductive ocean.

Over the coaxial and fiber-optic eras, supervisory and control systems were developed to monitor activity across the network. But these make the network vulnerable in ways earlier telegraph systems were not: by infiltrating a control system one person can effect changes across an entire network.
Although cables often remain in the periphery of our vision, the presence of hugs radio towers can signify cables beneath. Wireless and wired geographies often overlay one another.

November 15, 1901: "THE CAUSE OF A CABLE INTERRUPTION. A fault removed a few months ago from the Eastern Extension Telegraph Company's Sidney- Nelson section at as great a depth as 330 fathoms was found to contain a tooth firmly fixed in the core or interior portion of the cable containing the conductor, although it was protected by the usual sheathing of thick iron wires and outer coverings. An expert examination of the tooth proved it to belong undoubtedly to a shark, the exact variety of which could not be identified. Five species are known to exist in a depth of 300 fathoms, and one as deep as 500 fathoms."
Piracy can pose a problem for contemporary cable systems. Cable ships have to beware of pirates, especially in the Indian Ocean, and some cable crews arm themselves to prepare for hostile encounters.
Trawling – a form of fishing that entails dragging nets along the seafloor – sometimes includes cables in its catch, breaking the cables as it pulls them up.

Deregulation, privatization, and speculation about the growth of the Internet drove a global boom in cable laying in the late 1990s. Between 1988 and 2003, the voice paths across the Pacific increased 1.6 billion percent. Stewart Ash, who worked in cable installation at the time, recollects: “Cable manufacturers were building factories all over the place. We had a cable factory in Southampton in the U.K.. We had one in Portland, Oregon. We had another one in Australia. People were pushing out 100,000 kilometers of cable a year.”  This boom introduced new geographies to the undersea cable system.

“Dual-purpose” cables serve both scientific and telecommunications communities. These cables include sensors on the repeaters of transoceanic links, and as a result, could collect data on the movement of ocean currents; oxygen and greenhouse gas levels; seismic movements; and temperature. Proponents of dual-purpose cables argue that these systems could monitor for tsunamis and sea level rise. Dual-purposes systems, however, raise concerns about sovereignty – they hypothetically could be used for resource exploration or military surveillance.

One of the most critical locations of the telegraph station is the instrument room. Here, operators send and receive a multitude of messages using expensive technologies. If this room were attacked, as Fanning Island was during World War I, intruders would be able to destroy and intercept all communications. Today these instruments are not mechanical devices, but complex digital systems.
There is an entire marine maintenance industry that has to be funded by cable owners even in the absence of any breaks.

Remote and developing areas are often dependent on external assistance to set up cable systems, especially in tropical locations. Cables are more vulnerable at the fringes of the network, given the lack of insulation and often small scale of traffic, and operators must go further to interconnect with existing networks, often relying on international aid.
To protect cables from humans above, companies often bury their systems under the ground and the sea.

When the Vietnamese government permitted fishermen and soldiers to pull up cable laid before 1975 to sell as scrap, their plans went awry: fishermen pulled up two of the country’s three working fiber-optic lines (a significant decrease given that 80 percent of the country’s information traffic was carried by undersea cable). The government rescinded the right to salvage copper lines, began monitoring the route of the last cable, arrested the cable “thieves,” and planned an enlightenment campaign to inform fishermen of the dangers of cable theft.

Military strategists saw telegraph cables as the most efficient and secure mode of communication with and, by implication, control over their colonies, especially during wartime. Even when did not actually increase control over the sites it covered, these systems indexed the belief that undersea cables could secure economic and political investment.

During the coaxial period, cable companies made an effort to keep their stations from being seen as potential interception points for colonial power. One key element in these efforts was the process of “localizing” staff. Cable & Wireless brought students from over thirty countries to train at the Porthcurno Engineering College in England, as well as establishing overseas training schools in places such as Aden, Bahrain, Barbados, Brazil, Fiji, and Hong Kong. Cable & Wireless management also engaged in activities that would actively demonstrate their support of local people. The Chairman of the company, for example, gifted the first Gilbertese twins born on Fanning Island with a set of silver cups.

The remnants of telegraph stations often live solely on in the historical images of cable landings and the recorded memories of cable workers, scattered few and far between, and often buried in remote archives.

In the coaxial era, the surrounding social landscape of cable stations changed dramatically. Former colonies gained independence, the network’s stations were reconfigured as gateways to new nations. Yet, currents extending through the cable station could be perceived as a continuing intrusion of foreign power. In the 1960s, anti-British rioting in Indonesia cut communications to Malaysia and forced staff members to move to Singapore.

Many island nations imagine themselves not as simply an end-point for traffic, but as a hub for oceanic transactions. With only one link, it would be difficult to develop industries that would cease to operate if the one cable went out. To truly attract international investments, islands need redundant routes.

Cables are considered “critical infrastructure,” a term that means they are critical to a nation’s economic, financial, and social stability. In many places, security measures have been increased to control cable operations. A group of actors and agencies known as “Team Telecom” review applications and clear cable projects landing in the United States – this group has made it increasingly difficult to land on American soil.

The COMPAC and SEACOM coaxial cables were critical for the launch of the first American into space. Because of the need for “secure” circuits, the primary route between space control centers in California and Canberra, Australia extended via a cable from California to Sydney via Auckland and a back-up circuit was established via cables through Guam.
At this coastal cable station, you look out to see the view. A vast ocean expands in front of you, below which snakes the invisible submarine cable.
Cable systems can be vulnerable from within: an immense amount of time, energy, and manual labor are required to sustain undersea networks, and without it, the infrastructure would soon fail.

In early cable networks, the overland route was often the more dangerous option. While several sites on the Pacific Cable Board’s network were chosen to minimize the undersea segment, the company came to worry more about New Zealand’s “precarious overland route,” a notoriously unreliable link from Southport to Sydney, and a terrestrial line in Canada that was disrupted by winter storms,  bush fires, and “unusual electrical disturbances.” Eventually more “secure” undersea cables replaced each of these terrestrial lines.

In order to ensure that the line never drops, cable stations backup all critical equipment. As one technician explains: the “whole building is N+1” with a completely redundant system ready to take over if the first fails. Power is supplied from both ends of the cable: either end can sustain the system if the other goes out. Spares of critical equipment are kept in case of an emergency. In some stations, every cabinet in the room can be reached by two diverse routes; if any wire was accidentally cut, nobody loses service.

The cable’s beach landing has been the single most commemorated event in undersea cable history. Traces can be found in scrapbooks, home movie footage, companies’ publicity websites, and historical texts. To document or be present at a cable landing is to be a witness to the coming together of nations or worlds.

With the development of regeneration, less people were required at the cable station. Companies cut as much as seventy-five percent of their personnel. Cableman observed: this “had a demoralizing effect on the cable operator. It was not submarine telegraphy anymore—it was electronics. No longer was he the linchpin in the service. All he had to do was scrutinize tape automatically received, looking for mechanical failures before it was automatically retransmitted. It was very depressing.”

In response to increasing cable disruptions in the early twentieth century, cable companies proposed a “cable reserve.” Here, to protect cable systems trawling would be prohibited. In the telegraph era, these reserves were rejected, time and time again, by governments that privileged fishing interests over cable systems.
