In the nineteenth century, navigation was a formidable challenge. Charts were unreliable and shipwrecks occurred regularly. Large numbers of lives were lost and marine commerce was unreliable. To create better charts, marine scientists needed to determine longitude exactly – this depended on the ability to make astronomical observations in different locations at precisely the same time. Before undersea cables, time was not standardized across the world; but after continents were linked, mapmakers could compare the times at two cable stations and thus determine the longitude between them. When the first transpacific cable was laid, equipment was set up to use them for longitude experiments. By 1903, “longitude from the west clasped hands with longitude from the east, and the first astronomic girdle of the world was completed.”
Cable hubs, subject to airstrikes and invasion, are reduced to ruins in the aftermath of World War II. Many are never rebuilt.

In technical terms, a short-circuit or a “shunt fault” is a type of disconnection where the insulation is severed, but the conductor remains partially intact. This enables power to flow out into its proximate environment, and in some cases operations can continue. Short-circuiting is an intervention that does not completely sever a connection but instead breaks its layers of protection, feeding power to those around it.

Cable ships are enormous boats, capable of carrying hundreds of miles of submarine cable below their decks. On today’s ships expansive control systems and seafloor measurement technologies ensure that the cable will land precisely along a projected route.

For many, the ocean often seems like a threatening element to undersea transmissions, a material that would potentially intercept the electric signal and break the circuit. In reality, this threat is minimal. In some places, however, rising waters and intensified storms pose a threat to coastal cable stations.

Overland cables could become targets during popular revolts, as happened during the Boxer Rebellion in China when telegraph lines were sabotaged, cutting off communication between local diplomats and the British government. Australia’s transcontinental line was often disconnected by Aboriginals as well as the occasional lost cowboy who wandered across the landscape, cutting the line in order to be rescued by cable repairmen.

Cable stations are strategically valuable and have become targets during wartime. In 1914, the Germans attacked cable stations at both Fanning Island and Cocos Island in the Pacific and Indian Oceans with the aim of cutting major communication routes. During World War II, Japanese planes bombed the Sumay cable station in Guam. Severing undersea communications lines is not a key tactic in war today, but cable stations still have to be located on friendly and accessible territory and secured from potential threats. For this reason, places like Fanning Island are no longer strategic hubs, while locations such Guam are.

Here, those who control the cable systems meet resistance. In some places, populations around the station oppose the network, cutting it during times of conflict. In others, cables helped to generate a sense of nationalism for the region, in opposition to the British, who both governed the land and the cable network.

In the early telegraph network, cable systems were often laid to trade and transportation hubs. Networks were used to disseminate the latest prices of goods around the world, profoundly affecting local economies.
The cable permitting process is a lengthy, expensive, and often confusing undertaking for cable companies – one of the biggest hold-ups for cable development.
Signal traffic rarely moves in a straight line between origin and destination. More often our signals move in a circuitous route, determined by economic and geopolitical factors.

During the Cold War, there was a move toward infrastructural decentralization. These stations were tucked away in suburban or rural areas, seeminly more secure from the threat of anchors and the potential nuclear attacks. This strategy also protected cables from the rising costs of coastal property that made construction and maintenance more difficult, as well as swelling populations that could inadvertently disrupt cable systems.

Midway Island’s staff published The Gooney Clarion, “A Weekly Newspaper Published Every Now and Then.” An article in its Farewell edition records an “exciting day” on which a ship passed nearby the island, but “it is hardly necessary to add, did not stop.”

At the commemoration for the Tumon Bay cable station, Guam’s governor stated: “The station is a most welcome addition to our island, both functional and beautiful in its thin-shell, barrel vault roof design—the first of its kind on Guam… this roof contains exactly the same amount of concrete as a flat roof, yet is vastly more pleasing to the eye. ” It was designed by a local architect, utilized local labor and materials, and was applauded for its connections to its environment.

In the 1990s, telecommunications companies downsized. Alcatel reduced 48% of their workforce in undersea networks by 2001. AT&T cut 123,000 jobs from 1991-1995, 30% of its labor force. Much of the labor has been now been outsourced to network operations centers or delegated to computers.

Cable ships and a maintenance depot supporting the entire South Pacific region were once located at Fiji. As these ships had a largely Fijian crew, this boosted not only the region, but the local economy.

In 1964, following the Great Alaskan earthquake, a tidal wave came ashore at Port Alberni, disrupting mills and distributing cars and homes across the town. The COMPAC cable only seven miles from the city in a shallow part of the inlet, causing traffic to be re-routed through San Francisco. It was not the earthquake itself, but the shock of the tsunami that caused the trouble.

Although the Internet is often imagined as a “clean” and durable technology, something that will eventually be extended everywhere at little cost, this fails to register the extensive financial, social, and environmental investments required to establish cable systems. One recent report estimates that the annual cost to maintain cables ranges from $100 to $1000 per kilometer – millions of dollars per year.

British companies were able to dominate the early telegraph network not only due to their ability to master cable-laying technology and monopolize technical-support infrastructure, but also due to their development of an effective form of insulation using gutta percha, the rubber-like gum from Malaysian trees.

Nodes in our cable network require a stable political environment. One cable builder recounts his conversation with a government official: “I said, “Your army could take it over,” and they said, “Well, we don’t have an army.” “I see. Okay, your police.” “Police?” I said, “Okay, who in this country has got guns? Someone’s got guns. Someone with guns could take it over.” They said, “Yeah, you’re right.  Someone could.””

Cable companies must insulate their systems from social conflict. They develop strategies of insulation, ranging from fences to legal regimes, to ward off people that might interfere with their signal traffic.

This seaside manhole, covered in dirt, marks one of several cable landing points on O‘ahu’s coastline. Underground, connections extend directly to California, Oregon, Fiji, and Guam, and reach onward to Australia, Japan, and much of eastern Asia. Though they exist at the periphery of our vision, these structures allow access to the global undersea cable network.
